article_title: Texas flunks in health-care price transparency
article_text:
Texas flunks in health-care price transparency

Photo: nata777_7 - Fotolia The cost of healthcare

For the second year in a row Texas has received an F rating for failing to implement laws that would mandate price transparency in health care, a new report has found.

article_metadata.description: [...] Texas is far from alone as 44 other states also flunked, according to the third annual report card issued jointly by the advocacy and education organizations The Catalyst for Payment Reform and Health Care Incentives Improvement Institute.  Price transparency is considered a pillar of the Affordable Care Act to encourage patients to comparison-shop, which ultimately can help bring down health care costs.  Health policy experts say that while price transparency is a noble goal, it can be hard for patients to make decisions about their care because they might not fully understand all involved in complex medical treatments.  In a joint letter attached to their latest study, Suzanne Delbanco, executive director of Catalyst for Payment Reform, and Francois de Brantes, executive director of Health Care Incentives Improvement Institute, voiced optimism that states like Texas and other states could follow the lead of those that created databases of prices for patients to easily access.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam
